Two fins are lighter, and that’s the name of the game:  Weight.  Aerodynamically fins act like wings, as well as breaks.  The fuselage is a cylindrical lifting body encountering atmospheric drag on de-orbit.  A disc shape would be optimal in inducing drag to slow re-entry, though a flattened football shape would actually do better for directional control to break the flow to fly back; Lessing  heat build up as atmospheric density increases during descent.  The Space Shuttle with two wings flew back fine, though the tiles lost through the burn makes the large surface area of wings problematic.  Hence, two fins are optimum for control as breaks but also have L/D lift as wings far behind the center of mass working well in conventional rockets.

Fun experiment kids. I assume some of you may build and fly the Estes model rockets that have been around for 50 years. They have solid rocket engines and recovery systems etc. Lots of fun, but sometimes not allowed in areas that are prone to wildfires. Any way you know the drill, most kits have 3-4 fins on back and nose cone on front end. Launch, up, pop, down with a parachute or streamer. And you can learn a few things about rockets without sitting at the computer all day in you jammies! Outside, in the fresh air, as it were. But just for fun try to design and scratch build one that looks like this starship. If you can get it past your rocket club's range safety officer, it will have "interesting" flight characteristics! So, try it alone, out in a desert, or big park, with not too many spectators! Then you'll know why, despite weird (aka unstable) fin configuration, rockets have guidance, engine gimbals, and gyro systems to make them stable (aka safe) in flight. And yes, many modelers "fly" their rocket designs on the computer too, especially for the big powerful ones that are flown by the folks in the LDRS club!! BTW, that club is named: "Large and Dangerous Rocket Society", and their mile high plus flights are really awesome!! Watch some on YT. Finally, maybe you can design and build mini versions of those  gyro and engine gimbal systems for your starship model too. He he!! :D

Some fly-by-wire systems can even direct inputs from surfaces that don't work to those that are working.  So imagine a plane (like the DC-10 that crashed in Sioux City, Iowa) that has lost its vertical rudder.  The computer could route the pilot's rudder pedal movements to the engine(s).  The X-31 actually demonstrated this.  It's vertical tail was completely removed late in  the program with the plane remaining completely flyable even with just one engine.

I like the 2 fin version. Pretty much everything about it seems to be better. I think it definitely looks better too. But I think what is most important is what performs the best. And from what I can tell assuming it's implemented correctly. The 2fin version performs better. Unless they find reason for 3 fins.

But even if they use 3 fins. It's better to have more landing surface area. Giving you angular and directional stability. On touchdown. Something you don't have with three rigid fins. So landing struts is definitely the way to go. Also he's using the landing struts as a sources of drag. Which does have some flaws. But it seems like an efficient use of available weight and space on board. One device performing two functions.

However these are fairly critical systems. And if you lose one you may very well lose both. I guess it's good that they have 8. I would go ahead and even try to put 16 on there. In fact it may very well lower the weight. And increase structural rigidity. Not to mention the added benefit of redundancy and increase stability. Because there is a greater number of landing struts to spread the load. Each individual landing strut can be made from lighter materials.

Not to mention the actual size of each landing strut will be physically smaller and take up less individual space and wait. So even though they're would be more individual pieces. It would overall weigh less. And due to the increased number of landing struts. They can apply more physical Force. You might even consider 32. landing struts. Because that would also give you a higher degree of control using them as drag during reentry. And with that kind of redundancy. The issue of having one damaged is mostly nullified.
The only thing that concerns me is the landings legs need bigger shoes. mabe Falcon 9 style would be better in a newer form factor. For soft grown landings.

I kind of doubt that this will be its final, final form. This change may have gained some stability with the E and D part of entry, descent and landing but comes at the expense of stability with the L part. The ultimate intention is to land on unprepared ground on the moon and Mars. Six legs or not the main thing there is to have as wide a base as possible to avoid toppling over once landed. That's a really important part of a mission as it would make things a tad rough coming to rest with a horizontal aspect.  So for this first  prototype iteration it seems six legs in a ring and two lower "fins" is  more appropriate. Saving mass seems to be a high priority at this stage as the thing is already overbuilt like a battleship and has literally been slapped together as cheaply as possible. They just want to learn how to launch and land the thing at this stage and see how it holds up to re entry heating. The next iterations should be lighter and this will open up more options as to how the legs will be arranged. In the long run stability needs to be maximized for E D and L.

Hey, i've run across the notion that with aircrafts, unstability "means" more twitchy wich "means" more agility a few times now, and I can't help but make a comparaison between this and how suspension (& alignment) tuning works in cars, now i'm no professional but i play Forza and you can get quite deep into tuning since it's a semi simulation.
I think the reason I (think i) understood this concept in planes is because i've come to realise that was the case for cars.
So obviously in cars you just have the front wheels as user input for direction, but how the suspension is tuned (and therefore how the center of mass of the vehicle reacts to the road and steering input) will affect greatly on what turning the steering wheel will do, like night and day
If you want to be fast and agile (think of circuit racing), you have to get lower to the grond, stiffen suspension, tune alignment to maximize the "unstability" so the car can diverge from i'ts path easily, while still being controllable.
If you want the most stability (think of drag racing or a road car), you want to soften susp and get higher and you're setting up everything so that any slight input will not geartly affect the path of the car, while still being able to turn.
Softer/Stiffer suspension basically means more/less delay between inputs and the reaction of the center of mass.
Again, i'm no expert so feel free to criticize if something seems wrong!

We are optimizing for payload mass fraction and aerodynamic glide path. The rear fin, intuitively, would also add stabilization during vertical glide, but analysis shows it would likely cause side to side oscillations instead, especially at lower Mach numbers.

The top "canards" are larger to allow for more stability at dynamic re-entry angles, smaller brakes made it unstable when switching to powered landing mode with various payload distributions. Active vs passive cooling was also a consideration.

At around 11:30 you speculate about the potential advantages of having a fixed landing leg on the windward side of the vehicle.
I'm pretty sure this would be unstable for all of the reasons you described earlier, when talking about aero surfaces near the 'front' of a vehicle.

In a belly-flop, the windward side (not the pointy end) is the 'front'. Having a big fixed sail protruding from the front, directly into the airstream, is the most inherently unstable configuration; the two articulated fins would have to fight it constantly. In contrast, when the fixed fin is on the leeward side it is inherently stable, and helps add to the stability of the overall system, even if the two articulated fins have their center of pressure closer to the center of mass.

When considering the balance of aerodynamic forces, you have to factor in all three fins, not just the two articulated ones.

* Even at that wide it is no where near as stable as it looks.
* Yes, a 3 legged stool does not wobble like 4+ but you also need it exactly upright, so you need adjustment for the uneven surface anyway.
* If they have to move rapidly then having the weight of the legs is probably also a problem.
* With six legs it can probably also survive any one leg failing, or two if not right next to each other, or if you are really lucky, three with none right next to each other. Maybe you can survive two right next to each other if the other legs adjust to tilt the ship a bit.

Knowing they are going with a less robust landing system is a concern. A very tall vehicle like this is going to need, IMO, landing legs that have a very wide stance and high durability if it is expected to land on imperfect surfaces like the moon or mars. I would suggest legs mounted in a tripod configuration that would slide and extend along the external surface like the falcon rockets so it doesnt overcomplicate internal workings. This of course brings up other problems too because one of them needs shielding along with the stern mounted fins. It looks like the starship is headed back to its extremely early design. One of the things i like about elon musks idea is that the design looks more robust and tough, wich is something that is needed to inspire confidence in this odd vehicle.

Three body flaps (yeah, I said it) looked better, but separating the landing legs from them is a REALLY good idea. Both of those systems deal with a lot of environmental stresses, a failure to one shouldn't limit the use of the other, that could prove catastrophic.

Safety concerns are more important than aesthetic issues. A skyscraper spacecraft has to be safer for all concerned, for those in the craft and for those on the ground, also for the environment. Tim, Great video, very clear explanation as always. Once small nit pick. When the name of the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics is abbreviated and then spoken, the individual letters are pronounced. That is, it is "the N A C A" (like "the FBI"), not "NACA" pronounced like a word (like "NASA"). I worked at Langley Research Center in the mid-1970s with lots of former-NACA employees who were very particular about the pronunciation. Looking forward to the aerospike video.

I think another of those "plausible but not really" reasons that 2 wings are preferable to 3, is this:

It's known that reentry bow shocks, if detached from the main body, can help protect the vehicle from reentry heating. As you've mentioned, this is why capsules try to have as blunt a windward edge as possible, to reduce reentry heating.

Well, in the 3-fin design, the 2 wing roots of the body flaps would have been jutting forward into the stream, and might not have received the full protection of the bow shock. Even worse, they might have generated their own shockwaves that impinge on various parts of the structure, creating localised hotspots leading to burnthrough of the structure.

With only 2 wings, the wing roots are situated more further back relative to the airstream and generally fit the contour of the body and the deflected body flaps a lot better. That probably served a lot to simplify thermal protection.

The engineering required to have a pivoting hinge (where the fins meet the body of the craft) that can handle:
1) the torque of the hypersonic airflow
2) the heating of re-entry, and
3) the longitudinal loads of landing impact (or even just the static load of the gross vehicle weight at 1G on Earth)
is an incredible challenge to throw at the team, on top of all of the other challenges inherent in a vehicle of this size & complexity. Separating the functions relieves a huge amount of pressure and allows you to optimize each part for its specific function (rather than a compromised design that must tolerate the worst-case-scenario for all of its various functions).
